WRITING.TEXT: Completely forgot Preston's Spanish Holocaust which goes into the terror on both sides of the frontier, and if you're interested in historical memory, Giles Tremlett's Ghosts of Spain is terrific

I was lucky enough to study a couple of courses given by Judith Keene who wrote the marvellous "Fighting for Franco" about volunteers on the Nationalist side. It's an outstanding book, about something which isn't hugely well known http://www.amazon.co.uk/Fighting-For-Franco-International-Nationalist/dp/1852855932
Homage to Catalonia is my favourite book of all time.
I've also just finished "Telegram from Guernica" which a biography of GL Steer, the Times foreign correspondent who broke the news of the German bombing of the town. It's about Abyssinia some WW2 as well. It's an excellent book though http://www.amazon.co.uk/Telegram-Guernica-Extraordinary-George-Correspondent/dp/0571298869/ref=sr_1_1?s=books ie=UTF8 qid=1459620430 sr=1-1 keywords=telegram+from+guernica

WRITING.TEXT:
It's a cultural thing, perhaps?
English football is historically physical because that's what it was like from the start; the Scots introduced passing, which was regarded as revolutionary in England and that was 120 years ago.

Historically, Italian football has been famous for being defensive tactical than the rest of Europe. It was responsible for concepts like catenaccio ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catenaccio ) and whilst recently, Italian football has probably been better known for players like Pirlo or Del Piero, they used to produce *amazing* centre backs on a regular basis: Maldini, Cannavaro, Baresi.

My inclination is that more players *should* go abroad for the sake of being able to learn that adaptability. I'm hopeful at some point the Watford/Udine/Granada link up allows players from Watford to go experience it a little

you think that if players were regularly toppling down there that it wouldn't have been addressed? Up until the start of this season, I'd missed *maybe* 50 games in the last twenty years. If there was some list of dead dying players, a google of "player falling in the lower Rous at Watford" would produce something. It doesn't. Given the health safety concious nature of stadia design, if they thought there was a large risk, it would've been dealt with years ago. It hasn't, because THIS HASN'T HAPPENED BEFORE. There will *possibly* be changes (although I'm not sure what) for the next game, but there's not alot you can do when a stand has been built following a slope.
It's the oldest stand in the stadium now, and I'd wager that it's the next to be demolished as part of the extension plans for the stadium, but that ain't happening for a couple of years at least. I'm willing to bet that in that time, Ake will remain the only player to fall in there.
It's been there THIRTY YEARS. This is literally the first time it's happened. Behave.
yep. They're appalling seats

It's not a pit. The western stand at Vicarage follows the slope from north to south. As a result, there's a significant fall there. It's been there for 30 years, and as far as I know, this has never happened before. Certainly not in the 20 odd years I've been going, anyway

it's not a pit. The stand on the west side of pitch slopes upwards. Down that end, there's about a 5 foot fall (as you can see) the other end is non existent. It's been like that for thirty years, and as far as I can recall, this has never happened before.

WRITING.TEXT:
At Watford, I'm absolutely convinced that Gifton Noel-Williams would've been capped for England if his knee wasn't destroyed by Paul Butler. Had 14 goals by January in his first season at division one (Championship) level at 18/19, was constantly improving. Strong as an ox, great in the air and capable of scoring goals like this (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-qAsSt6dyc)
Had his knee destroyed about ten minutes later, spent a year or more out and was never the same player.
I'm convinced that he'd have been twice the player Emile Heskey was (I know that sounds like damning with faint praise, but given he spent a good deal of the 00s playing for England as the big lump for Owen/Rooney/someone else to play off of, I think it's a good comparison)

WRITING.TITLE: Sam Wallace on the Pozzo-tive effect of Watford's Italian owners

WRITING.TEXT:
Historically in England it's always been a busy period.
In the 50s 60s games were played on Xmas Day. That must've been awesome.
Jamie George has got to be wondering what on earth he has to do to get a run as first choice.
In fairness, the Saffacens thing was perfectly fair when Johannes Rupert bought into the club a dozen South Africans turned up. But, long term, that's enabled players like Faz, Fraser co develop.

We would have. I used to sell 50/50 tickets before the game until we were all sacked before this season started, and the lady responsible for us on match day worked in the accounts team. She confirmed at the first game back after the Pozzo family took over that (a) we were less than an hour from going in administration and (b) the events with the safe were as reported.
I've since spoken to other people who worked at the club during the Baz reign, and apparently he used to pay the builders of the Red Lion with cash from the bar takings, and things got so tight with regards to paying bills that one of the managers of the catering used to have to HIDE THE CASH (!!!!) from Baz so she could use it to actually pay suppliers.

Ridiculous level of arrogance. He's a good, and at times entertaining manager, but needs to pull his head in.
His behaviour with Carneiro the other medic was disgusting as well.

WRITING.TITLE: Six years is a long time in football: 16th December, 2009: Watford FC stand on the brink of administration
